ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



C&S Wholesale Grocers' senior management is not only committed to offer superior service, but to also maintain a safety and environmental program to promote a safe environment for all its employees and the surrounding community.  The Corporate Compliance Team assists the facility in administering safety and environmental policies. The Corporate Compliance Team is made up of the following personnel:



?    Senior Director of Corporate Refrigeration

?    Corporate Manager of Refrigeration

?    Senior Manager Environmental Compliance

?    PSM-RMP Regulatory Manager

?    Corporate Manager of Facilities Compliance

?    OSHA Regulatory Manager



The Maintenance Supervisor periodically evaluates the health and safety practices of facility employees to ensure compliance, and oversees implementation of the safety and environmental programs.  These programs include forklift safety, hazard communications, lockout/tagout, Hazardous Materials Emergency Business Plan, employee safety manuals, manufacturer's documentation, Emergency Response, as well as the Risk Management Plan.



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE



C&S - Westfield is located at 53 Summit Lock Road in Westfield, Massachusetts which is approximately 2 miles north of the I-90.  The facility and the refrigeration system began operation in the early 1990s with a major expansion of the facility completed in early 2004.  The area immediately surrounding the facility is rural.



The primary business of C&S - Westfield is to provide refrigerated warehousing and storage for various food products.  In order to conduct operations, the facility maintains a refrigeration system containing approximately 62,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia, a regulated substance.  The refrigeration system, consisting of piping, valves, and equipment, cycles ammonia through various physical states (high pressure liquid, low pressure liquid, low pressure vapor, high pressure vapor, an

d then back to high pressure liquid) in order to provide refrigeration for glycol chilling, dock operations, cold/freezer storage, and ice making.  Typical operating conditions range from 5" Hg on the low pressure side of the system to 170 psig on the high side of the system.  



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



In order to operate the ammonia refrigeration system, the facility complies with the following risk management regulations:



1) OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM); and

2) EPA's Risk Management Program (RMP).



These regulations impose numerous requirements on the facility to ensure the safety of the public and on-site workers.  The following summarizes the key compliance programs that have been implemented by C&S - Westfield to prevent the accidental release of ammonia from the facility.  The Operating Procedures program ensures that the ammonia system is operated in a safe manner.  The Training program ensures that personnel fully understand how to perform their jobs in a safe manner.  The Mechanical Integrity program ensures that the ammonia system is in proper working condition based upon routine testing, inspections, and maintenance according to manufacturer's specifications and industry standards.  The Management of Change program ensures that process modifications are implemented in a safe manner.  The Pre-Startup Safety Review program ensures that adequate safety measures are in place before ammonia is introduced into a process.  The Hot Work Permit program ensures that C&S - Westfield's employees and contractors perform hot work (e.g. welding) in a safe manner.  The Contractor Safety program ensures that contractors understand the hazards of ammonia and must take specified precautions to safely complete job requirements.



It is important to note that the refrigeration system has been designed with several safety features to prevent the accidental release of ammonia.  For example, the compresso

rs are equipped with safety mechanisms that will cause the units to shut down if operating conditions exceed designated safety limits.  Also, level indicators, alarms, and switches are installed in key points within the system to monitor the supply of liquid ammonia and to ensure that a vessel is not overfilled.  The facility has also installed ammonia sensors in the Engine Room, in the cold storage areas, and in the ice making room which will alert operators in the event of an ammonia detection. 



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



There has been one release at the facility that was reportable to the State of Massachusetts Department of Environmental Protection. Details of this incident are included in the RMP*eSubmit. There have been no federally reportable incidents nor any that resulted in serious injuries or offsite consequences within the last five years (January 2009 - January 2014). 



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



The facility has an Emergency Action Plan (plan) in effect at the facility.  This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:  

- save lives;

- minimize and avoid injuries;

- protect the environment; and

- minimize property damage.



The Plan provides the notification procedures and evacuation routes for emergencies that may arise at the facility. The Facility is non-responding and has personnel trained to support the HazMat response team if required (up to 300 ppm of ammonia).



There is a specific program (CEHS-0042) which outlines the training, qualifications and procedures for authorized ammonia Incident responders and observers.  This Plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year to ensure compliance with the PSM and RMP regulations.  Facility personnel receive annual training regarding the emergency procedures and the Emergency Response Team holds regular drills.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

In December 1995, the refrigeration system was thoroughly examined for safety hazards by way of a Process Hazard Analysis (PH

A).  In addition, three Five Year Revalidations of the initial Process Hazard Analysis have been conducted.  

?    1st Revalidation: October 2003 

?    2nd: September 2008

?    3rd: August 2013



The PHA Revalidations consisted of a:

- Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) study (1st and 2nd);

- What-If study (3rd);

- series of safety checklists; and

- facility inspection.

The mitigation measures (recommendations) include additional training, key maintenance-related tests/inspection, and enhanced emergency response policies and procedures.  All recommendations resultant from the most recent revalidation study are due to be addressed by 8/2014.
